bibl.title: Letter from Philip Showalter Hench to Estela Agramonte Rodriguez Leon, April 15, 1948

div1.p: Hench writes about returning Agramonte's papers to her and informing Kean, Truby and Lawrence Reed about important points which the papers clarify. He informs her about his success in lobbying the Cuban government for funds to preserve Building No. 1.

div1.head: Letter from Philip Showalter Hench to Estela Agramonte Rodriguez Leon, April 15, 1948
div1.opener:
April 15, 1948
Senora Estela Agramonte Rodriguez Leon
Calle K No. 254
Havana, Cuba
My dear Senora:
div1.p:
On my return home I found a small mountain of work to dispose of and
was delayed in having copied the most interesting material concerning your
father which you most kindly loaned me. Now it is all copied and according
to our conversation, I am first sending (air mail, registered mail) by separate
post the photostatic copies of all the material.

After you have informed me of their safe arrival, I will return to
you the original data in any way you wish, either by (1) air mail registered
or insured postage or (2) through the Cuban Embasy from Washington; I will be
in Washington May 11 - 12; or (3) through Dr. Pedro Nogueira of Havana (of
whom you may have heard as he is much interested in the whole yellow fever
story). He will attend the International Congress on Tropical Medicine in
Washington May 9 - 18 but will be in the the States about four weeks so he
would not be able to get it to you until mid-June. (I realize you do not
want any Cuban to examine the data but I could wrap it and seal it. I'm sure
he'd be glad to deliver it to you in person. However you may wish it returned
by one of the first two routes.

I am most grateful to you for your real courtesy in going to so much
trouble to find the material and then in lending it to me. It has cleared up
several important points on which I (and the published record) were much con-
fused. As I promised, I will now call some of it to the attention of certain
men in this country (e.g. Generals Kean and Truby and General Reed, Walter
Reed's son) who will be most interested to see it. Also I am writing both
the Curator of the National Archives and the Adjutant Genera., U. S. Army and
will straighten out the record regarding your father's absence from Havana in
September - October 1900 (when Lazear died) so that the record of his trip to New
York on military duty will be recorded. I have had extra photostats made and
I will deposit them in the appropriate permanent files pertaining to your father.

By separate post I am sending you photostats of the following:
1. Autograph record of yellow (fever) mosquito bites - 8 pages
(Also a photograph of pages 1 and 8).
2. Carroll article - 5 pages and envelope with Guiteras note.
3. Discuss del Agramonte, pronunciado en la ceremonia del des
cubrimiento del busto del Finlay - 8 pages.
4. Beauperthuz, Finlay y la comision Americana - 7 pages.
5. Agramonte speech planned for the inauguration of Lazear's
tablet in Columbia University - 2 pages.
6. Two letters of October 5, 1900, written in New York (2+1=3)
Senora Estela Agramonte Rodriguez Leon
- 2 -
April 15, 1948
7. Reed to Agramonte, May 25, 1900 - 2 pages.
8. " " November 14, 1899 - 3 pages.
9. " " August 25, 1899 - 2 pages.
10. Agramonte to Adjutant General - February 12, 1903 - 2 pages.
11. Wood to Agramonte, September 22, 1900 - 1 page.
12. Steinhart to Agramonte - October 18, 1900 - 1 page.
13. Scott to Agramonte, September 20, 1900 - 1 page (front and back
= 2 pages).
14. Paymaster General to Agramonte, January 13, 1903 - 3 pages
(2 pages, one both sides).
15. Ten letters, Sternberg to Agramonte - April 19, 1898 to January 26,
1900 - 12 pages.
16. Reed to Agramonte, May 2, 1901; envelope and 2 folders - 7 pages.
17. Statement signed by Spanish volunteers, November 22, 1900 - 3 pages.
18. Agramonte to Sternberg, December 24, 1899 (page and endorsements -
2 pages).
19. Hemmeter to Agramonte - 3 letters and small note - 5 pages and note.

Apropos this last item, you may recall that a copy of one (two?) letters
from your father to Hemmeter was attached. Several times you offered me your
father's letters to Hemmeter but I didn't take it with me as I insisted you'd
already given me a copy. On my return I was chagrined to find that your father's
letter to Hemmeter of which I have a copy is dated February 2, 1913. I do not
have your father's letter of November 30, 1912 to Hemmeter mentioned in Hemmeter's
letter January 18, 1913 (first sentence) and also February 1, 1913. I wish indeed
that I could borrow your copy of your father's letter (to Hemmeter) dated November
30, 1913. I was so certain your father had only written him one letter, I didn't
examine closely enough what you handed me. Would it be possible for you either to
lend me the missing letter of November 30, 1912 (without which I cannot fully
understand Hemmeter's replies or your father's objections), either sending it
to me airmail registered so that I can copy it here (making extras for you) or
having it copied (photostated) in Havana at the Alabama Photo Studio (Obispo
Street, I think). I would greatly appreciate this.

You may have heard or noted in a recent Havana paper that I was ap-
parently successful in my request to the Cuban Government to take steps to pre-
serve the caseta (Building One) at Camp Lazear (Finca San Jose). I saw various
officials, the Vice-President, officials in the Ministerio Obras Publicas, and
others. They telegraphed me that $50,000 had been ordered to be set aside as a
start to preserve the caseta. I am very glad of this.

I wish you could be here between May 12 and 20. I have been asked to
give the “principal oration” at the evening session of the International Congress
on Tropical Medicine, at the memorial on the Conquest of Yellow Fever (Washington).
Then on May 20 in New York City will be unveiled in the Hall of Fame the bust of
Reed. I have sent those in charge a photograph of your father and also recommended
that they reproduce the Cornwell painting which also includes your father, because
even though the ceremony unveils a bust of Reed, his colleagues must be recognized.
I'll send you a program of each of these events if I can.

If you can possibly do it, without interfering too much with your very
busy life, I do hope you can continue to look for data concerning your father's
connection with the yellow fever work. It is so important to bring out all the
facts. Especially, do I hope you can run across correspondence between your
Senora Estela Agramonte Rodriguez Leon
- 3 -
April 15, 1948
father and the editor of the Scientific Monthly because I am sure it would
account for the strange contradictions put into your father's mouth in that
article, which I suspect were put in by a re-write man to “pep-up” or dramatize
the article for the laymen. To find such an explanation would be very important.

Again thank you so much and please give the kind regards of Mrs. Hench
and me to your husband and son.
div1.closer: Sincerely, P. S. Hench, M. D. PSH:alc
